description: From French alambic, from Medieval Latin alembīcus, from Arabic الإِنْبِيق‎ (al-ʔinbīq), from Ancient Greek ἄμβιξ (ámbix, “cup, cap of a still”).

entries.meaning: An early chemical apparatus, consisting of two retorts connected by a tube, used to purify substances by distillation.
examples: Ideal beauty is not the mind’s creation: it is real beauty, refined and purified in the mind’s alembic, from the alloy which always more or less accompanies it in our mixed and imperfect nature.
